newsitem.title: USA: Warner-Lambert sees 6-8 pct 96 EPS growth.
newsitem.headline: Warner-Lambert sees 6-8 pct 96 EPS growth.

text.p: Warner-Lambert Co said on Tuesday that it continued to expect its reported earnings per share to grow six to eight percent in 1996.

"The growth of our pharmaceutical business is providing strong momentum in advance of the new product introductions planned for 1997," said Melvin Goodes, Warner-Lambert chairman and chief executive officer, in a statement with the company's third quarter results.

The company reported earnings of $2.74 a share in 1995, including one-time gains, which is the number from which the company expects the six-to-eight percent gain for reported 1996 earnings, a spokesman said.
Warner-Lambert reported third quarter earnings of $0.56 compared with $0.48 a year ago. The 1995 number excludes a one-time gain of $0.31 from the sale of the company's PRO toothbrush business.
It beat the First Call consensus of $0.54 a share.
The company said its third quarter sales of $1.77 billion, compared with $1.78 billion a year ago, were trimmed by three percent due to the impact of the strong U.S. dollar.
Its third quarter pharmaceutical sales rose eight percent to $604 million.

Its consumer health care segment's worldwide sales fell five percent to $691 million in the third quarter. The segment's sales reflect the reclassification of Halls cough tablets to the confectionery segment for 1996 and 1995, Warner-Lambert said.
Its confectionery segment's third quarter sales fell three percent to $473 million.
